On physical examination, the right testis is palpable in the scrotum. However, the left hemiscrotum is underdeveloped, and the left testis is not palpable in the scrotal sac or inguinal canal, even with manipulation. There is no inguinal mass or tenderness. On arrival, he is in extremis, and resuscitative efforts are initiated. Despite immediate intervention, he succumbs to his injuries within minutes. questions.text: A 58-year-old lady with a previous history of WLE for DCIS presents to the OPD with complaints of a firmness in the region of the scar without a palpable lump. What is the next best step in this case?

choices.text: Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his left chest after a road traffic accident. His BP is 85/69mm Hg and HR is 110bpm. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracostomy

 

The chest X-ray shows evidence of tension pneumothorax, such as a collapsed left lung and shift of mediastinal structures to the right. In the clinical context of shock and respiratory distress, immediate needle thoracostomy is life-saving and should be performed without delay.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. eFAST: Used for trauma assessment, but this patient needs urgent decompression of the tension pneumothorax first.
 

Option B. Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids: Useful in shock but does not address the cause of respiratory compromise in tension pneumothorax.
 

Option D. Intubate the patient: Not indicated prior to relieving tension pneumothorax, as airway management alone will not resolve lung collapse.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

The clinical scenario and X-ray findings indicate a femoral hernia, which typically presents as a swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Associated pain, vomiting, and features of intestinal obstruction point toward strangulation, requiring urgent intervention.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adhesions: Common cause of intestinal obstruction, but would not present as a groin swelling below the pubic tubercle.
 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: Swelling would be above and medial to the pubic tubercle, differing from the femoral hernia location.
 

Option D. Direct hernia: Occurs due to weakness in the abdominal wall, presenting as a swelling above the pubic tubercle, not below and lateral.

choices.text: Cervical esophagostomy is performed in unstable patients
Perforation is most commonly seen on the left anterolateral wall
﻿﻿﻿Gingko leaf sign may be seen on CXR
﻿﻿﻿A gastrograffin study may be performed

questions.text: A 21-year-old man, after a bout of binge drinking and vomiting, presents with severe pain in the chest and dyspnea with a crunch on palpation in the back. On clinical examination, there is rigidity in the upper abdomen. The chest X-ray shows a Naclerio V sign. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Perforation is most commonly seen on the left anterolateral wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. His vitals are stable. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. All of the following should be done except:
What other finding would be expected in this 25-year-old male with abnormal pelvis MRI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute painful red eye

 

This MRI image demonstrates bilateral sacroiliitis, a hallmark of ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in young men. Ankylosing spondylitis is frequently associated with extra-articular manifestations, most notably acute anterior uveitis, which presents as an acute painful red eye with photophobia and blurred vision. The connection is because both sacroiliitis and uveitis are seronegative spondyloarthropathy features and often co-exist in affected patients. Recognizing the ocular involvement is crucial in evaluating systemic disease activity and providing holistic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated RF: Rheumatoid factor (RF) is typically negative in ankylosing spondylitis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The absence of RF helps differentiate it from rheumatoid arthritis, making this finding unlikely.

 

Option C. Atlanto-axial dislocation: Atlanto-axial dislocation is classically seen in advanced rheumatoid arthritis or juvenile idiopathic arthritis, not in ankylosing spondylitis. Although cervical spine involvement (like fusion) is seen later in AS, dislocation is rare.

 

Option D. IV disc calcification: Intervertebral disc calcification is usually associated with degenerative spinal diseases or metabolic conditions, not with ankylosing spondylitis or sacroiliitis. AS typically causes syndesmophyte formation and spinal ankylosis  but not disc calcification

questions.text: A child presented with difficulty in walking. The wrist radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rickets 

 

The wrist X-ray shows classic features of rickets, which include metaphyseal fraying, widening (splaying) of metaphyseal ends, and cupping, most clearly visible at the distal radius and ulna. These radiological changes arise due to defective mineralization of the growing bone and cartilage, usually from vitamin D deficiency. Clinically, rickets presents with gait disturbances, bone pain, and deformities such as bowing of the legs due to weak and soft bones. Early changes often appear at rapidly growing growth plates like the wrist and knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scurvy: Scurvy shows a white line of Frankel (dense provisional calcification), ring epiphysis, and ‘Pelkan spur’ at metaphyses, but metaphyseal fraying and splaying are not seen. It results from vitamin C deficiency and manifests with gum bleeding and subperiosteal hemorrhage.

 

 

Option B. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents radiographically with generalized osteopenia, bone deformities, and multiple fractures. Metaphyseal changes like fraying and cupping are not seen, and the clinical picture includes blue sclerae and hearing loss.

 

 

Option D. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia leads to shortening of long bones, especially proximal segments, and a characteristic trident hand (separation between fingers). Classic rickets changes in the metaphysis are not features of achondroplasia, which primarily affects endochondral ossification

 

 

Examples of the characteristic radiological features of achondroplasia in the above image: 

 

  • A - Plain X ray, lateral view of the skull showing frontal bossing, thick calvaria and relatively small skull base.
  • B - Plain X ray, AP view of spine showing caudal narrowing of interpediculate distance.
  • C - Plain X ray, lateral view of vertebrae showing platyspondyly with posterior scalloping and exaggerated lumbar lordosis. 
  • D - Plain X ray, AP view of the pelvis showing square iliac wings, fl at acetabular roof and narrow sacrosciatic notch. 
  • E - Plain X ray of long bones of right upper limb showing short broad long bones mainly in the humerus. 
  • F - Plain X ray of long bones of lower limbs showing short broad long bones, metaphyseal fl aring of the distal femoral ends taking the form of inverted-V (chevron) shaped metaphyseal notch. 
  • G - Plain X ray of both hands showing brachydactyly & trident con fi guration

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

  • Urinoma is a collection of urine in the retroperitoneum due to urine leak after renal trauma.
  • First-line management in a hemodynamically stable patient with urinary extravasation is internal urinary diversion via ureteral stent placement.
  • This allows urine to bypass the site of injury, promotes healing, and prevents infection or further collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical repair and exploration: Surgical repair is reserved for severe injuries with persistent leak despite stenting or associated vascular/collecting system injury.

 

Option D. Pigtail drainage of collection: Percutaneous drainage (pigtail) is usually adjunctive if the urinoma is infected. 

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone is insufficient if the urinoma is enlarging or symptomatic.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the submandibular gland. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. USG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

The ultrasound image shows a hyperechoic structure with posterior acoustic shadowing within the right submandibular duct, indicating a salivary stone (sialolith). This finding, combined with symptoms of pain and swelling that worsen during meals, is classic for sialolithiasis.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Pleomorphic adenoma: Usually presents as a well-defined, hypoechoic, solid mass in the gland, not a calcified lesion in the duct.
 

Option C. Osteoma of floor of mouth: Rare, and would be seen as a dense bony structure, not within the submandibular duct.
 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Appears as enlarged, rounded lymph nodes in the cervical chain, unrelated to ductal stones.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the skeletal survey of a 10-year-old boy with recurrent fractures?
The injury shown in the radiograph can result in:

A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plummer-Vinson Syndrome

 

The barium swallow image shows a cervical esophageal web resulting in partial obstruction, and the clinical context includes dysphagia, regurgitation, and a history of iron deficiency anemia. These findings are classic for Plummer-Vinson syndrome[aka Patterson Kelley Syndrome]

 

Other Options:


Option A. Shatzki ring: Typically a lower esophageal (distal) web, not in the cervical esophagus, and not associated with iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Option B. Zenker's diverticulum: Seen as a posterior outpouching in the pharyngoesophageal area, presenting with regurgitation and halitosis.

 

 

Option C. Esophageal leiomyoma: Appears as a smooth, submucosal mass on imaging, not as a thin mucosal web.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of?

A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. All of the following may be missed on eFAST except?

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An 45-year old female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing USG, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a 6mm stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

  • The patient has a common bile duct stone (choledocholithiasis) with biliary dilation, which can lead to cholangitis or pancreatitis if left untreated.
  • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the first-line therapeutic procedure for CBD stone removal before cholecystectomy.
  • After CBD clearance, elective cholecystectomy is performed to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy – Performing surgery without addressing the CBD stone risks retained stone complications, including cholangitis or pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Elective cholecystectomy – Correct only after CBD clearance via ERCP; otherwise, patient remains at risk.

 

Option D. MRCP – Diagnostic only; not therapeutic. ERCP both diagnoses and treats CBD stones. Useful when the diagnosis is exact doubtful on USG.

choices.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

questions.text: All of the following is true about the given except?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph?

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? 

 

  1. Endotracheal intubation
  2. Chest X-ray
  3. Plain CT
  4. ICD insertion
questions.solution: Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.
